description: From Middle English resoun, reson, from Anglo-Norman raisun (Old French raison), from Latin ratiō, from ratus, past participle of reor (“reckon”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *h₂reh₁- (“to think”), reanalysed root of *h₂er- (“to put together”). Doublet of ration and ratio.

entries.meaning: That which causes something: an efficient cause, a proximate cause.
examples: The reason this tree fell is that it had rotted.

entries.meaning: A motive for an action or a determination.
examples: The reason I robbed the bank was that I needed the money.
If you don't give me a reason to go with you, I won't.

entries.meaning: An excuse: a thought or a consideration offered in support of a determination or an opinion; that which is offered or accepted as an explanation.
(logic) A premise placed after its conclusion.
(uncountable) Rational thinking (or the capacity for it); the cognitive faculties, collectively, of conception, judgment, deduction and intuition.
examples: Mankind should develop reason above all other virtues.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) Something reasonable, in accordance with thought; justice.
examples: I was promised, on a time, To have reason for my rhyme.

verbs.description: reason (third-person singular simple present reasons, present participle reasoning, simple past and past participle reasoned)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To deduce or come to a conclusion by being rational
examples: "I had," said he, "come to an entirely erroneous conclusion which shows, my dear Watson, how dangerous it always is to reason from insufficient data.  […] "

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To perform a process of deduction or of induction, in order to convince or to confute; to argue.
(intransitive, obsolete) To converse; to compare opinions.
(transitive, intransitive) To arrange and present the reasons for or against; to examine or discuss by arguments; to debate or discuss.
examples: I reasoned the matter with my friend.

entries.meaning: (transitive, rare) To support with reasons, as a request.
(transitive) To persuade by reasoning or argument.
examples: to reason one into a belief; to reason one out of his plan

entries.meaning: (transitive, with down) To overcome or conquer by adducing reasons.
(transitive, usually with out) To find by logical process; to explain or justify by reason or argument.
examples: to reason out the causes of the librations of the moon
